items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTAMENDEDTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Eddie Garcia, Board President, and Lan Nguyen, Vice PresidentSUBJECT:Discussion/Action regarding Proposed 10% Reduction in Board Monthly Stipend and Contribution to Benefits PackageEast Side Union High School District students, certificated employees, and classified employees are making sacrifices to minimize the impact of the $19.8 million deficit facing the district in fiscal year 2010-2011 as a result of cuts caused by the State’s budget problems.   Although the Board's stipend and a voluntary Cabinet salary reduction cannot alone resolve the budget deficit, the Board and administration should lead by example so the East Side Union High School District can continue its mission to deliver a quality education to our students.East Side Union High School District Board Members are being asked to consider taking a 10% reduction in their Board monthly stipend and to contribute to the benefits package provided as part of the Board stipend compensation.FISCAL IMPACT:Savings to General Fund To Be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE:General Fund:  Program 711-- Board of TrusteesRECOMMENDATION:We respectfully request that the Board of Trustees to approve the following actions:Approve a 10% reduction in the Board’s monthly stipend of $750 beginning in the 2010-2011 fiscal year;Direct the administration to determine the feasibility of the Board of Trustees making a contribution to health benefits within the current group benefits package the District negotiates with providers; and,Encourage members of the administrative Cabinet to consider a voluntary 3% reduction to current salaries to be effective at the beginning of the 2010-2011 fiscal year.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Interim Director of Instructional ServicesSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action regarding the Comparison of Educational Models on Calero PresentationThis is a presentation comparing educational models for Calero. Four years ago East Side Union High School District began to explore the possibility of opening its own community day school. The financial situation of our District has drastically changed and it is necessary to explore alternative models. This presentation will discuss the pros and cons of opening a Community Day School and compare it to an educational model that encompasses a Continuation School, Independent Study Program, and a Post Senior Program for our severely disabled students.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve a multi-school model for the Calero property.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and PlanningSUBJECT:Approve Proposed Modernization Plan for Calero High SchoolThe Board of Trustees approved the purchase of Calero School in 2008.  The intent of acquiring the school was for the District to continue providing quality programs for District students.In order to provide the necessary classroom spaces, construction modernization will need to occur to accommodate any Board approved educational programs. The scope of work for the modernization plan will include demolition, interior renovations, and site work.  The scope of work will be within the budget presented to the Board in February, 2009.The Facilities Bond Team will be present to answer questions from the Board of Trustees.FISCAL IMPACT:$9.5 MillionFUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed   modernization plan for Calero High School and for the administration to   proceed with the modernization efforts as appropriate.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2010-11 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education ProgramOverview:The East Side Adult Education Program is part of a six program Career Technical Education consortium to receive Carl Perkins funding.  Under its guidelines adult education agencies who can not generate $50,000 in grant funding may apply for funding under a consortium model.  The four partners in the consortium are Metropolitan Adult Education, Campbell Union High School District, Mountain View-Los Altos Adult Education, Santa Clara Adult Education, and Sunnyvale-Cupertino Adult Education.  With the assistance of our consortium members, the East Side Adult Education has served as the lead partner in this consortium and is charged with submitting the application, monitoring the progress toward goal achievement, and evaluating the Carl Perkins plan annually.Accomplishments:Utilizing information for Central Santa Clara County from the Employment Development Department, input from the five Adult Education Program Advisory Committees, and staff and student surveys, the CTE Consortium Advisory Committee identified two industry sectors and related career pathways addressed in this five year plan.  Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in Health and Science which will focus on Clinical Nursing, Medical Assistant, and Home Health Aide Assistant career pathways.  The second industry sector is Information Technology, which will focus on Administrative Assistant, Database Administrator, Support & Services Technician, Desktop Publishing, and Accounting career pathways.  The Adult Education Programs in the consortium offer a thriving program for the completion of a secondary education and English language development and providing career learning opportunities in health, medicine, and information technology that have numerous entry and advancements options will complement our programs. FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006,Section 132RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2010-11 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education Program.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Contracts for Professional Services over $50,000The following Contracts for Professional Services over $50,000 is being recommended for Board approval.1.  Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerA. GarofaloJ. Rono, PhD.D. BertrandMay 6, 2010 through and including May 5, 2013$427,500.00Measure EEducation Center/Calero SchoolAlan GarofaloJune Rono, PhD.East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a Contract for Construction Management Services for Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. for the Calero High School Modernization Project. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero project as defined in item 10.02.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.N/ASelection Process The District completed a formal Request for Qualifications (RFQ), RFQ-02-08-09 which went to the Board for approval of the recommended “Measure E & G Pre-Approved Construction Management Firms (CM) List” on March 10, 2009.  With this list in place, the District then requests from all four of the pre-approved to submit a “Construction Management Selection Questionnaire (CMSQ)” which will include the cost and project team being proposed.  In this case, back on June 9, 2009 Facilities requested CMSQ from three of the four firms.  At that time Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. was selected to be recommended to the Board for approval.  However, at that time and at subsequent meetings this project was removed from the Board agenda.For this Board meeting, purchasing requested that new proposals be obtained due to the age of the old proposals and the fact that the hard cost had increased significantly which would affect the cost proposals previously submitted.  Facilities was able to secure two new proposals but the third vendor was not able to provide a new proposal “given the timeframe in which it is required”.  RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees enter into an Agreement with Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc., for the Term May 6, 2010 through and including May 5, 2013 for the Provision of Construction Management Services for the Calero High School Modernization Project contingent upon contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero project as defined in item 10.02. 2.  Sugimura Finney Architects Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerA. GarofaloJ. Rono, Ph.D.D. BertrandMay 6, 2010 through and including May 5, 2013$641,250.00Measure EEducation Center/Calero SchoolAlan GarofaloJune Rono, Ph.D.East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a Work Authorization Agreement for Architectural Design Services with Sugimura Finney Architects for the Calero High School Modernization Project. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero project as defined in item 10.02.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.N/ASelection Process The District completed a formal Request for Qualifications (RFQ), RFQ-03-07-08 which went to the Board for approval of the recommended pool of District Architects on June 19, 2008. With this list in place, the District requested three Architectural firms to provide an “Architect Selection Questionnaire (ASQ)” which includes a cost and project team proposal.  In this case, back on June 9, 2009 Facilities requested ASQ’s from three firms.  At that time Sugimura Finney Architects was selected to be recommended to the Board for approval.  However, at that time and at subsequent meetings this project was removed from the Board agenda.For this Board meeting, purchasing requested that new proposals be obtained due to the age of the old proposals and the fact that the hard cost had increased significantly which would affect the cost proposals previously submitted.  New proposals were obtained and Sugimura Finney Architects is still the recommended Architect based on the new proposals obtained.  RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees enter into a Work Authorization Agreement for Architectural Design Services with Sugimura Finney Architects for the Calero High School Modernization Project for the term of May 6, 2010 through and including May 5, 2013. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero project as defined in item 10.02.

Foothill High School – Buildings B, C, & E ModernizationBid BidOpeningLegalAdvertisementsAdvertisementDate(s)Project DescriptionB-10-09-10Estimated:$1.2 MillionApril 20, 2010Emailed or Faxed to all Pre-Qualified BiddersMarch 29, 2010Work includes but is not limited to, the modernization of 2, 2,600+ square feet classroom Bldgs, abatement, roofing, finishes, and new fire alarm, HVAC, and electrical systems.Bid Results:CONTRACTORBASE BIDALTERNATE #1ALTERNATE #2UNIT PRICE #1UNIT PRICE #2Beals Martin and Associates Inc.$1,399,669.00$42,914.00$53,889.00$135.00$219.00West Coast Contractors$1,416,000.00$50,000.00$25,000.00$200.00$1,500.00Albay Construction$1,442,000.00$57,000.00$36,000.00$250.00$600.00Valhalla Builders$1,464,000.00$27,255.00$20,000.00$200.00$800.00Rodan Builders$1,486,000.00$32,000.00$16,000.00$150.00$150.00John Plane Construction$1,569,000.00$40,000.00$49,500.00$300.00$1,500.00Best Contracting$1,760,000.00$76,500.00$18,000.00$180.00$4,500.00Alternate #1 is the OCIP (Owner Controlled Insurance Program); Alternate #2 is the cost to completely replace all mansard roof siding, trim, and flashings on a per building basis.  It was noted in the bid documents (see attached Addendum #2) that this cost can be applied to other buildings as required.  We recommend the acceptance of Alternate #2 for all three buildings for a total of $161,667.00.Alternate #1 is the contractor’s provided insurance for the project. Keenan and Associate provided a quote of $41, 849.42 for a savings of $1,064.58.  If the District manages the 10% allowance and is able to keep the spending of the allowance to a minimum Keenan will reimburse the District the difference as the construction cost will be less thereby the cost of the insurance will be lower.FISCAL IMPACT:$1,561,336.00  This amount includes the base bid amount of $1,399,669.00 which includes a 10% allowance and $161,667.00 for Alternate #2 applied to all three buildings.  The District does not recommend Alternate #1 nor the Unit Price #1 or Unit Price #2 to be included in the contracted amount.FUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended to the Board of Trustees award the above listed bid for the Foothill High School – Buildings B, C, & E Modernization Project to Beals Martin and Associates, Inc., as the lowest responsible bidder; and to award a contract/policy to Keenan and Associates to provide the Statewide Educational Wrap Up Program (SEWUP) for this project.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and PlanningSUBJECT:Approve the Request for Additional Facilities of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School for the 2010-2011 School YearPursuant to Education Code Section 47614 (Proposition 39) and Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 11969.1 through 11969.11, KIPP San Jose Collegiate has provided East Side Union High School District with the required annual written request for facilities for the 2010-2011 school year.KIPP San Jose Collegiate is a district approved charter school and based upon the administration’s review of their request, KIPP San Jose Collegiate meets the requirement for additional facilities.  Currently, KIPP San Jose Collegiate uses twelve (12) relocatable classrooms at Independence High School and they are in need of six (6) additional classrooms for the 2010-2011 school year.  At this time, the district has the additional relocatable classrooms available to meet their request at the same location.FISCAL IMPACT:Lease cost of relocatable classrooms to be paid by KIPP San Jose CollegiateFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for additional facilities of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School for the 2010-2011 school year
